pages.text: Confused about how bullet damage is calculated?$(br2)You might be looking at the base damage values for bullets, thinking, '$(o)Why are these all so low? Surely bullets aren't THAT weak?$()'. Well, you're right, they can be much stronger.

pages.title: Velocity Bonus
pages.text: All bullets have a bonus applied for their velocity at the time of impact. The formula for this bonus is as follows:$(br2)$(l)delta distance vector length x base damage$()$(br2)The maximum damage is clamped at $(l)2.147483647E9D$(), so if a bullet happens to accelerate some absurd amount, it won't deal more damage than this.

pages.title: Crit Bonus
pages.text: Every time you fire a firearm, you have a $(l)10%$() chance for a bullet to be critical. The critical bonus is as follows:$(br2)$(l)random(current damage / 2 + 2)$()$(br2)Then, the critical bonus is added to the current damage. If the damage were to somehow exceed $(l)2147483647L$(), then it stops adding more.

pages.title: An Example
pages.text: Say you fire an iron musket ball at a creeper, and the bullet velocity is $(l)3$() (roughly five blocks away). Iron musket balls have a base damage of $(l)2.65$(). So now, calculate the velocity bonus:$(br2)$(l)2.65 x 3 = 7.95$()$(br2)Now that's quite a bit of damage!
